page.title: 125th anniversary of the overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii

revision.comment: /* 1993 */clean up, replaced: lead by → led by
revision.text:
The '''125th anniversary of the overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii''' was marked by a march of thousands of people from [[Mauna Ala]] (the Hawaiian Royal Mausoleum) to the [[Iolani Palace]] to commemorate [[Liliʻuokalani]]'s forced removal from the throne and raise the Hawaiian Kingdom Flag at the exact moment it was lowered in 1893.<ref name="urlwww.staradvertiser.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/17/breaking-news/thousands-march-to-iolani-palace-to-mark-anniversary-of-overthrow/ |title=www.staradvertiser.com |author= CRAIG T. KOJIMA|date= January 17, 2018|work= |publisher= Honolulu Star Advertiser|quote= |accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref>
==History and background== ===1893=== On July 6, 1846, [[U.S. Secretary of State]] [[John C. Calhoun]], on behalf of [[John Tyler|President Tyler]], afforded formal recognition of Hawaiian independence under the reign of [[Kamehameha III]].<ref name="State1895p12">{{cite book|author=United States. Dept. of State|title=Papers Relating to the Foreign Relations of the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0d0tAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA12|year=1895|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|page=12}}</ref> As a result of the recognition of Hawaiian independence, the Hawaiian Kingdom entered into treaties with the major nations of the world<ref name="Opportunity1977">{{cite book|author=United States. Congress. House. Committee on Education and Labor. Subcommittee on Economic Opportunity|title=Economic Opportunity Act of 1964, Amendments of 1977: Hearings Before the Subcommittee on Economic Opportunity of the Committee on Education and Labor, House of Representatives, Ninety-fifth Congress, First Session, on H.R. 7577...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=njDRAAAAMAAJ|year=1977|page= 92|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office}}</ref> and established over ninety legations and consulates in multiple seaports and cities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Historical Collections of The Hawaiian Islands - Treaties, Conventions, and International Agreements of the Kingdom of Hawai'i|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/hi/keepers/tre01.txt|website=usgwarchives.net|publisher=usgwarchives.net|accessdate=December 30, 2014}}</ref> The [[House of Kamehameha|Kamehameha Dynasty]] was the reigning monarchy of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]], beginning with its founding by [[Kamehameha I]] in 1795, until the death of [[Kamehameha V]] in 1872 and [[Lunalilo]] in 1874.<ref name="HomansMunich1997">{{cite book|author1=Margaret Homans|author2=Adrienne Munich|title=Remaking Queen Victoria|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yC4n0FfjVB0C&pg=PA147|date=October 2, 1997|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-57485-3|pages=147–}}</ref><ref name="Wikipedians">{{cite book|author=Wikipedians|title=The United States of America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HolwxdMeTwYC&pg=PA451|publisher=PediaPress|pages=451–|id=GGKEY:2CYQCESKTB7}}</ref> The kingdom would continue under the [[House of Kalākaua]] for another 21 years until its overthrow in 1893 when a coup d'état against Queen Liliuokalani was supported by U.S. Marines.<ref name="Siler2012">{{cite book|author=Julia Flynn Siler|title=Lost Kingdom: Hawaii's Last Queen, the Sugar Kings and America's First Imperial Adventure|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jbBvWQ8LGKEC&pg=PA220|date=January 2012|publisher=Atlantic Monthly Press|isbn=978-0-8021-2001-4|pages=220–}}</ref>
===1993=== [[File:Bruce Asato.jpg|thumb|The Bruce Asato image from the January 17, 1993 march as it appeared on the cover of the Honolulu Advertiser]] On January 17, 1993 a march was held from the [[Aloha Tower]] to the Iolani Palace to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the event. The march of 15,000<ref name="Trask1993">{{cite book|author=Haunani-Kay Trask|title=From a native daughter: colonialism and sovereignty in Hawai'i|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FRtzAAAAMAAJ|date=1 May 1993|page= 100|publisher=Common Courage Press|isbn=978-1-56751-009-6}}</ref><ref name="Tengan2008">{{cite book|author=Ty P. Kāwika Tengan|title=Native Men Remade: Gender and Nation in Contemporary Hawai‘i|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G5SxZ-bw3pYC&pg=PA64|date=29 September 2008|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0-8223-8937-1|page=64}}</ref> people was led by the [[Hawaiian sovereignty movement|Ka Lāhui]] and was part of the ''ʻOnipaʻa'', an observance of the queen's overthrow.<ref name="Geography1998">{{cite book|author=University of Hawaii at Hilo. Dept. of Geography|title=Atlas of Hawai'i|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f0efIh9CV94C&pg=PA182|year=1998|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-2125-8|page=182}}</ref> The 1993 observance took its name from Queen Liliuokalani's motto, ''"ʻOnipaʻa"'' (to remain steadfast). 20,000 people are estimated to have met at the palace for a series of events that included a re-enactment of the overthrow and speeches from activists and educators like [[Haunani-Kay Trask]] who said; ''"We are not Americans! We are not Americans! We will die as Hawiians! We will never be American!"'' Trask and others from the University of Hawaii at Manoa worked closely with film-makers Puhipau and John Lander of the production company ''Nā Maka o ka 'Āina'' to create the film; "Act of War:The overthrow of the Hawaiian Nation". The film helped bring the findings of Hawaiian historians like Trask, [[Jonathan Kamakawiwo'ole Osorio]] and [[Lilikalā Kameʻeleihiwa]] to a larger and broader audience. In 1993, Trask also released her well known book; "From a Native Daughter: Colonialism and Sovereignty in Hawaii" that dealt with such topics as corporate tourism, academic exploitation, suppression of Native epistemology and histories as well as the high number of ancient sites including burials that have been destroyed <ref name="Goodyear-Ka’opuaHussey2014">{{cite book|author1=Noelani Goodyear-Ka’opua|author2=Ikaika Hussey|author3=Erin Kahunawaika'ala Wright|title=A Nation Rising: Hawaiian Movements for Life, Land, and Sovereignty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m9LZBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT39|date=27 August 2014|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=978-0-8223-7655-2|pages=39–40}}</ref> An iconic image from the cover of her book shows the 1993 march as it neared the palace. The book's cover photo was taken by photographer Ed Greevy however, Honolulu-Star Advertiser photographer Bruce Asato also captured the moment and appeared on the front page of the newspaper. Both image depict the organizers of the march stopping to allow elders to enter the grounds of the palace first.<ref name="urlPressReader.com - Connecting People Through News">{{cite news |url=https://www.pressreader.com/usa/honolulu-star-advertiser/20180108/281505046611619 |title=Remembering the Overthrow|author= Timothy Hurly|date= January 8, 2018 |publisher= Honolulu-Star Advertiser|format= |work= |accessdate=2018-01-19}}</ref>
Marking the 122nd anniversary of the overthrow, activists organized the "Queen Liliuokalani Kingdom Restoration Spiritual Walk" in 2015, beginning the march from [[Mauna Ala]] (the Royal Mausoleum) down to the Iolani Palace, to Liliuokalani's statue and then to the capital rotunda. Organizer's concerns included crown lands being sold illegally, the desecration of sacred grounds and the moving of ancient burials for the ongoing rail project.<ref name="urlHawaiian activists rally on anniversary of kingdom’s overthrow | KHON2">{{cite web |url=http://khon2.com/2015/01/17/hawaiian-activists-rally-on-anniversary-of-kingdoms-overthrow/ |title=Hawaiian activists rally on anniversary of kingdom’s overthrow | KHON2 |format= |work= |accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref>
==2018 march and commemoration== ===Preparation=== When a false nuclear ballistic missile alert went off 4 days before the event, one of the organizers, Kaukaohu Wahilani, mentioned how the US military is linked to colonialism; ''"It was only through the might of the American military that the overthrow was successful"''.<ref name="urlMissile Scare Motivates Activists Who Fear Militarys Presence">{{cite web |url=http://www.civilbeat.org/2018/01/missile-scare-motivates-activists-who-fear-militarys-presence/ |title=Missile Scare Motivates Activists Who Fear Military's Presence |author= Anita Hofschneider|date= January 16, 2018|publisher= Honolulu Civil Beat|quote= |accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref> The event, ''ʻOnipaʻa Kākou'', made a solemn day a memorable event featuring a rally after the march with speeches and hula and ceremonial protocols and prayers.<ref name="urlCeremony marks 125 years since overthrow of Kingdom of Hawaii | KHON2">{{cite web |url=http://khon2.com/2018/01/17/special-all-day-event-for-125th-anniversary-of-the-overthrow/ |title=Ceremony marks 125 years since overthrow of Kingdom of Hawaii | KHON2 |author= Jenn Boneza|date= January 17, 2018|format= |work= |publisher= Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc.|quote= |accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref> Beginning one week before the event, [[Hinaleimoana Wong-Kalu|Hinaleimoana Wong]] began holding the Mana Ka Lahui Mele Workshops for the community to learn songs being used during the day.<ref name="url125th anniversary marks overthrow - The Garden Island" /> [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]] students participated and helped print specially designed T-shirts created by Tita Coloma just for the day.<ref name="urlThousands prepare ahead of overthrows 125th anniversary - Honolulu, Hawaii news, sports & weather - KITV Channel 4">{{cite web |url=http://www.kitv.com/story/37280961/thousands-prepare-ahead-of-overthrows-125th-anniversary |title=Thousands prepare ahead of overthrow's 125th anniversary - Honolulu, Hawaii news, sports & weather - KITV Channel 4 |author= Moanike'ala Nabarro|date= January 16, 2018|publisher= KITV4 Island News|quote= |accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref>
===March=== [[File:Queen_Liliuokalani_color.jpg|thumb|upright|Image of Queen [[Liliʻuokalani]] carried in 125th anniversary march from Mauna Ala to the Iolani Palace.<ref name="125 Hawaii News Now - KGMB and KHNL" />]] The full event began with protocol observances at Mauna Ala with a march to the palace for the flag raising and then to the statue of Queen Liliʻuokalani where ceremonial offerings were made.<ref name="url125th anniversary marks overthrow - The Garden Island">{{cite web |url=http://www.thegardenisland.com/2018/01/13/hawaii-news/125th-anniversary-marks-overthrow/ |title=125th anniversary marks overthrow - The Garden Island |author= Staff writer|date= January 17, 2018|format= |work= |publisher= The Garden Island|accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref> The crowd entered through the main gates of the palace grounds as oli (chants) were performed and participants carried torches, Hawaiian flags and two purple [[Kāhili]] which were carried alongside a marcher carrying Queen Liliuokalani's portrait.<ref name="125 Hawaii News Now - KGMB and KHNL">{{cite web |url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37270656/125-years-ago-the-hawaiian-flag-was-lowered-america-then-took-ove |title=125 years later, overthrow of Hawaii's last monarch marked with - Hawaii News Now - KGMB and KHNL |author= Dillon Ancheta|date= January 17, 2018|work= |publisher= Hawaii News Now|quote= |accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref>

{{redirects|500s BC|the decade|500s BC (decade)}} {{Centurybox|-6}} The '''6th century BC''' started the first day of [[600 BC]] and ended the last day of [[501 BC]].
This century represents the peak of a period in human history popularly known as [[Axial Age]]. This period saw the emergence of five major thought streams springing from five great thinkers in different parts of the world: [[Buddha]] and [[Mahavira]] in India, [[Zoroaster]] in Persia, [[Pythagoras]] in Greece and [[Confucius]] in China. [[Pāṇini]], in [[India]], composed a grammar for [[Sanskrit]], in this century or slightly later.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=CKLxjjXqAsQC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=panini+BCE&source=web&ots=Gakie80Lfx&sig=oEJkmNhpxv9H9qavcz-XKGdallE&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result Ritual and mantras: rules without meaning] Google Books</ref> This is the oldest still known grammar of any language.
In [[Western Asia]], the first half of this century was dominated by the '''[[Neo-Babylonian Empire|Neo-Babylonian]]''' or '''[[Chaldean dynasty|Chaldean]]''' empire, which had risen to power late in the previous century after successfully rebelling against [[Assyria]]n rule. The [[Kingdom of Judah]] came to an end in [[586 BC]] when Babylonian forces under [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] captured [[Jerusalem]], and removed most of its population to their own lands. Babylonian rule was ended in the 540s by [[Cyrus the Great|Cyrus]], who founded the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian Empire]] in its place. The Persian Empire continued to expand and grew into the greatest empire the world had known at the time.
In [[Iron Age Europe]], the [[Celts|Celtic]] expansion was in progress. China was in the [[Spring and Autumn period]].
*[[Mediterranean]]: Beginning of [[Greek philosophy]], flourishes during the [[5th century BC]] *The late [[Hallstatt culture]] period in [[Eastern Europe|Eastern]] and [[Central Europe]], the late [[Nordic Bronze Age|Bronze Age]] in [[Northern Europe]] *[[East Asia]]: the [[Spring and Autumn period]]. [[Confucianism]], [[Legalism (Chinese philosophy)|Legalism]] and [[Moism]] flourish. [[Laozi]] founds [[Taoism]] *West Asia: During the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian empire]], [[Zoroaster]], a.k.a. Zarathustra, founded [[Zoroastrianism]], a [[Dualistic cosmology|dualistic]] [[philosophy]]. This was also the time of the [[Babylonian captivity]] of the ancient Jews. *[[History of India|Ancient India]]: the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] and [[Mahavira]] found [[Buddhism]] and [[Jainism]] *The decline of the [[Olmec]] civilization in [[Central America]]
==Events==
=== [[590s BC]] === [[File:Olmeca head in Villahermosa.jpg|thumb|150x150px|'''Monument 1''', an [[Olmec colossal heads|Olmec colossal head]] at La Venta]]
* Mid-6th century BC: Foundation of [[Temple of Olympian Zeus (Athens)]]. * [[598 BC]]: [[Jehoiachin]] succeeds [[Jehoiakim]] as [[King of Judah]]. * 16 March [[597 BC]]: [[Babylonia]]ns capture [[Jerusalem]], replace Jehoiachin with [[Zedekiah]] as king. * [[595 BC]]: [[Psammetichus II]] succeeds [[Necho II]] as King of [[History of ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. * [[594 BC]]: [[Solon]] appointed [[Archon]] of [[Athens]]; institutes [[democracy|democratic]] [[reforms]]. * [[590 BC]]: Egyptian army sacks [[Napata]], compelling the [[Kingdom of Kush|Cush]]ite [[court]] to move to a more secure location at [[Meroe]] near the [[sixth Cataract]].<ref>{{cite web| title = History of the SUDAN| publisher =www.historyworld.net| year = 2007| url =http://www.historyworld.net/wrldhis/PlainTextHistories.asp?historyid=aa86 | accessdate =3 August 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070714044043/http://www.historyworld.net/wrldhis/PlainTextHistories.asp?historyid=aa86| archivedate= 14 July 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
=== [[580s BC]] === [[File:Nebukadnessar II.jpg|thumb|150px|upright|An engraving on an eye stone of onyx with an inscription of [[Nebuchadnezzar II]]]] [[File:Nuremberg chronicles f 59r 2.png|thumb|150px|upright|Medieval image of [[Thales]]]] * [[589 BC]]: [[Apries]] succeeds [[Psammetichus II]] as King of [[History of ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. * [[588 BC]]: [[Nebuchadrezzar II of Babylon]] begins siege of [[Jerusalem]]; some sources set the date at [[587 BC]]. * [[587 BC]]/[[586 BC]]: Jerusalem falls to the [[Babylonia]]ns, ending the [[Kingdom of Judah]]. The conquerors destroy [[Solomon's Temple]] and exile the land's remaining inhabitants. [[Babylonian Captivity]] for the Jews begins. * [[586 BC]]: death of [[King Ding of Zhou]], King of the [[Zhou Dynasty]] of [[China]] * 28 May [[585 BC]]: A [[solar eclipse]] occurs as predicted by [[Thales]], while [[Alyattes of Lydia|Alyattes]] is [[Battle of the Eclipse|battling]] [[Cyaxares]]. This leads to a truce. This is one of the cardinal dates from which other dates can be calculated. * [[585 BC]]/[[584 BC]]: [[Astyages]] succeeds [[Cyaxares]] as King of the [[Medes]]. * [[585 BC]]: [[King Jian of Zhou]] becomes King of the Zhou Dynasty. * [[583 BC]]: The Babylonians begin a siege against [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]]. * [[582 BC]]: [[Pythian Games]] founded at [[Delphi]] (traditional date). * [[580 BC]]: [[Cambyses I of Anshan|Cambyses I]] succeeds [[Cyrus I of Anshan|Cyrus I]] as King of [[Anshan (Persia)|Anshan]] and head of the [[Achaemenid dynasty]] (approximate date). * [[580 BC]]: [[Isthmian Games]] founded at [[Corinth, Greece|Corinth]] (traditional date)
=== [[570s BC]] ===
* [[579 BC]]: [[Servius Tullius]] succeeds the assassinated [[Lucius Tarquinius Priscus]] as [[King of Rome]] (traditional date). * [[573 BC]]: [[Nemean Games]] founded at [[Nemea]] (traditional date). * [[572 BC]]: Death of [[King Jian of Zhou]], King of the [[Zhou Dynasty]] of [[China]]. * [[571 BC]]: [[King Ling of Zhou]] becomes King of the [[Zhou Dynasty]] of [[China]]. * [[570 BC]]: [[Amasis II]] succeeds [[Apries]] as King of [[History of ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. * [[570 BC]]: [[Pythagoras]] of [[Samos]] is born (approximate date). * [[570 BC]]: End of the Babylonian siege against the city of Tyre with a partial victory by the Babylonians. It was the longest siege of the city in history, lasting 13 years.
=== [[560s BC]] === [[File:Kroisos stake Louvre G197.jpg|thumb|150px|upright|[[Croesus]] on the pyre, Attic red-figure amphora]] [[File:Persepolis - carved Faravahar.JPG|thumb|150px|upright|[[Faravahar]], a symbol of [[Zoroastrianism]] in [[Persepolis]]]] * [[568 BC]]: [[Aramatle-qo|Amtalqa]] succeeds his brother [[Aspelta]] as [[Monarch|King]] of [[Kingdom of Kush|Kush]]. * [[562 BC]]: [[Amel-Marduk]] succeeds [[Nebuchadnezzar II|Nebuchadnezzar]] as [[King of Babylon]]. * [[560 BC]]: [[Neriglissar]] succeeds [[Amel-Marduk]] as [[King of Babylon]]. * [[560 BC]]/[[561 BC]]: [[Croesus]] becomes [[King of Lydia]]. * [[560 BC]]: [[Peisistratos (Athens)|Pisistratus]] seizes the [[Acropolis]] of [[Athens, Greece|Athens]] and declares himself [[tyrant]]. He is deposed in the same year.
=== [[550s BC]] ===
* [[550s BC]]: [[Carthage]] conquers [[Sicily]], [[Sardinia]] and [[Corsica]]. * [[559 BC]]: [[Cambyses I of Anshan|King Cambyses I of Anshan]] dies and is succeeded by his son [[Cyrus the Great|Cyrus II the Great]]. * [[558 BC]]: [[Hegias of Athens|Hegesias]] removed as [[Archons of Athens|Archon]] of [[Athens]]. * [[558 BC]]: The [[China|Chinese]] state of [[Jin (Chinese state)|Jin]] defeats its rival [[State of Qin|Qin]] in battle. * [[556 BC]]: [[Peisistratos (Athens)|Pisistratus]] is exiled from [[Athens, Greece|Athens]] to [[Euboea]]. * [[556 BC]]: [[Labashi-Marduk]] succeeds [[Neriglissar]] as [[King of Babylon]]. * [[556 BC]]/[[555 BC]]: [[Nabonidus]] succeeds [[Labashi-Marduk]] as [[King of Babylon]]. * [[550 BC]]: [[Abdera, Thrace|Abdera]] is destroyed by the [[Thrace|Thracians]]. * [[550 BC]]: [[Cyrus II the Great]] overthrows [[Astyages]] of the [[Medes]], establishing the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian Empire]]. * [[550 BC]]: The [[Mumun Pottery Period|Late Mumun Period]] begins in the [[Korean peninsula]].
=== [[540s BC]] ===
* [[547 BC]]: [[Croesus]], [[Lydia]]n [[monarch|King]], is defeated by [[Cyrus the Great|Cyrus]] of [[Achaemenid Empire|Persia]] near the River [[Halys River|Halys]]. * [[546 BC]]: [[Cyrus the Great|Cyrus]] of [[Persia]] completes his conquest of [[Lydia]], and makes [[Pasargadae]] his [[Capital (political)|capital]]. * [[544 BC]]: People of [[Teos]] migrate to [[Abdera, Thrace]] to escape the yoke of [[Iran|Persia]]. * [[544 BC]]: [[King Jing of Zhou (Ji Gui)|King Jing of Zhou]] becomes King of the [[Zhou Dynasty]] of [[China]]. * [[543 BC]]: [[Prince]] [[Vijaya of Sri Lanka|Vijaya]] establishes a [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]] dynasty of [[Sri Lanka]]. * [[543 BC]]: [[Peisistratos (Athens)|Pisistratus]], tyrant of [[Athens]], purifies the island of [[Delos]] (approximate date). * [[540 BC]]: [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] city of [[Thesprotia|Elea]] of [[southern Italy]] founded (approximate date). * [[540 BC]]: [[Achaemenid Empire|Persians]] conquer [[Lycia]]n city of [[Xanthos]], now in southern [[Turkey]] (approximate date).
=== [[530s BC]] === [[File:Pasargadae 2.jpg|thumb|150px|upright|[[Tomb of Cyrus]] in [[Pasargadae]]]] * [[539 BC]]: [[Babylon]] is conquered by [[Cyrus the Great]], defeating [[Nabonidus]]. * [[538 BC]]: Return of some [[Jews]] from [[Babylonian captivity|Babylonian]] exile who build the [[Second Temple]] about fifty years after the destruction of the [[First Temple]], from [[520 BC]]–[[516 BC]]. * [[537 BC]]: [[Jew]]s transported to [[Babylon]] are allowed to return to [[Jerusalem]], bringing to a close the [[Babylonian captivity]]. * [[536 BC]]: According to tradition, the [[Biblical]] [[prophet]] [[Daniel (biblical figure)|Daniel]] receives an angelic visitor.<ref>[http://bible.gospelcom.net/cgi-bin/bible?passage=daniel+10%3A4&language=english&version=NLT Daniel 10:4] Bible Online</ref> * [[534 BC]]: [[Lucius Tarquinius Superbus]] becomes [[King of Rome]]. * [[534 BC]]: Competitions for [[tragedy]] are instituted at the [[City Dionysia]] [[festival]] in [[Athens]]. * [[530 BC]]: [[Cambyses II]] succeeds [[Cyrus the Great|Cyrus]] as [[King of Persia]].
=== [[520s BC]] === [[File:Astasahasrika Prajnaparamita Victory Over Mara.jpeg|thumb|150px|upright|[[Gautama Buddha]]]] * [[528 BC]]: [[Gautama Buddha]] attains [[Enlightenment (Buddhism)|Enlightenment]], and begins his ministry. He founds [[Buddhism]] in [[India]]. It becomes a major [[world religion]]. * [[526 BC]]: [[Psammetichus III]] succeeds [[Amasis II]] as [[King]] of [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. * [[525 BC]]: [[Cambyses II]], ruler of [[Iran|Persia]], conquers [[History of ancient Egypt|Egypt]], defeating [[Psammetichus III]]. This is considered the end of the [[Twenty-sixth dynasty of Egypt|Twenty-sixth Dynasty]], and the start of the [[Twenty-seventh dynasty of Egypt|Twenty-seventh Dynasty]]. * [[522 BC]]: [[Smerdis of Persia|Smerdis]] succeeds [[Cambyses II]] as ruler of [[Iran|Persia]]. * [[522 BC]]: [[Babylon]] rebels against [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] rule. * [[521 BC]]: [[Darius I]] succeeds [[Smerdis]] as ruler of [[Iran|Persia]]. * [[521 BC]]: The [[Babylonia]]n rebellion against [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] rule is suppressed * [[520 BC]]: [[King Dao of Zhou]] becomes King of the [[Zhou Dynasty]] of [[China]] but dies before the end of the year * [[520 BC]]: [[Cleomenes I]] succeeds [[Anaxandridas II]] as [[King of Sparta]] (approximate date)
=== [[510s BC]] === [[File:Lao Tzu - Project Gutenberg eText 15250.jpg|thumb|150px|upright|Image of [[Laozi]]]] * [[519 BC]]: [[King Jing of Zhou (Ji Gai)|King Jing of Zhou]] becomes [[Monarch|King]] of the [[Zhou Dynasty]] of [[China]]. * [[516 BC]]: [[Indian subcontinent]]—Occupation of [[Punjab region|Punjab]] is completed by the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] [[Monarch|King]] [[Vistaspa]]. * 12 March [[515 BC]]: Construction is completed on the [[Temple in Jerusalem]]. * [[514 BC]]: [[King Helü of Wu]] establishes the "Great City of Helü", the ancient name for [[Wuxi]], as his [[Capital (political)|capital]] in [[China]]. * [[513 BC]]: [[Darius I of Persia|Darius the Great]] subdues the [[Dacia|Getae]] and east [[Thrace]] in his war against the [[Scythians]]. *[[512 BC]]: The [[Kingdom of Macedonia]], under King [[Amyntas I]], becomes a vassal state to the [[Achaemenid Empire]]. * [[510 BC]]: [[Hippias (son of Pisistratus)|Hippias]], son of [[Peisistratos (Athens)|Pisistratus]] and [[tyrant]] of [[Athens]], is expelled by a popular revolt supported by [[Cleomenes I]], [[monarch|King]] of [[Sparta]] and his forces. * [[510 BC]]: End of reign of [[Lucius Tarquinius Superbus]], last King of the traditional seven [[Kings of Rome]]. * [[510 BC]]: Establishment of the [[Roman Republic]]. * [[510 BC]]: [[Demaratus]] succeeds [[Ariston (king of Sparta)|Ariston]] as [[Kings of Sparta|King of Sparta]] (approximate date).
=== [[500s BC (decade)|500s BC]] ===
* 13 September [[509 BC]]: The [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus|Temple of Jupiter]] on Rome's [[Capitoline Hill]] is dedicated on the Ides of September. * [[508 BC]]: Office of ''[[pontifex maximus]]'' created in [[Rome]]. * [[507 BC]]: [[Cleisthenes]], [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] [[reform]]er, takes power and increases [[democracy]]. * [[506 BC]]: [[Battle of Boju]]: Forces of the [[Wu (state)|Kingdom of Wu]] under [[Sun Tzu]] defeat the forces of [[Chu (state)|Chu]]. * [[505 BC]]: First pair of [[Roman Republic|Roman]] [[consul]]s elected. * 4 December [[502 BC]]: [[Solar eclipse]] darkens [[Egypt]] (computed, no clear historical record of observation). * [[502 BC]]: The [[Latin League]] defeats the [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]]s under [[Lars Porsena]] at [[Aricia, Italy|Aricia]]. * [[502 BC]]: [[Naxos, Greece|Naxos]] rebels against [[Iran|Persia]]n domination sparking the [[Ionian Revolt]]. * [[501 BC]]: [[Cleisthenes]] reforms [[democracy]] in [[Athens]]. * [[501 BC]]: [[Naxos Island|Naxos]] is attacked by the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian Empire]]. * [[501 BC]]: In response to threats by the [[Sabines]], [[ancient Rome|Rome]] creates the office of [[Roman dictator|dictator]]. * [[501 BC]]: [[Confucius]] is appointed governor of [[Chung tu]]. * [[501 BC]]: [[Gadir]] (present-day [[Cádiz]]) is captured by [[Carthage]] (approximate date). * [[500 BC]]: [[Bantu languages|Bantu]]-speaking people migrate into south-west [[Uganda]] from the west (approximate date). * [[500 BC]]: [[Refugee]]s from [[Teos]] resettle [[Abdera, Thrace|Abdera]]. * [[500 BC]]: [[Darius I]] of [[Iran|Persia]] proclaims that [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] be the [[official language]] of the western half of his empire. * [[500 BC]]: Signifies the end of the [[Nordic Bronze Age]] civilization in [[Oscar Montelius]] periodization system and begins the [[Pre-Roman Iron Age]]. * [[500 BC]]: Foundation of first [[republic]] in [[Vaishali (ancient city)|Vaishali]] [[Bihar]] [[India]].
=== Unknown Events ===
* [[Achaemenid Empire|Persians]] begin to seize power. * [[History of Persia|Persians]] dominate [[eastern Mediterranean]]. * The [[Iran|Persians]] under [[Darius I]] and later [[Cyrus the Great|Cyrus]] invade [[Transoxiana]]. * [[Carthage]]'s [[merchant]] empire slowly dominates the [[western Mediterranean]]. * ''[[Tao Te Ching]]'' written (traditional date). * [[Confucius]] formulates his [[ethical]] system of [[Confucianism]], which proves highly influential in [[China]]. * The [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]] emigrate to [[Sri Lanka]]. * [[Book of Psalms]] written (apparent date). * [[Abkhazia]] is colonized by the [[Ancient Greece|Greeks]]. * Emergence of the [[Proto-Germanic]] [[Jastorf culture]]. * Temple B, [[Selinus]], [[Sicily]], is built. * The [[Autariatae]] communities united and expanded towards the [[Triballi]] in the east and the [[Ardiaei]] in the south.

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} The '''Arab Winter'''<ref name=telegraph>{{cite web|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/9753123/Middle-East-review-of-2012-the-Arab-Winter.html |title=Middle East review of 2012: the Arab Winter | work = The Telegraph |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| publisher = The Jerusalem Post | url = http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Analysis-Arab-Winter-is-coming-to-Baghdad-359348 |title = Analysis: Arab Winter is coming to Baghdad | work = The Telegraph | accessdate = October 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/us/2014/April/Expert-Warns-of-Americas-Coming-Arab-Winter/ |title=Expert Warns of America's Coming 'Arab Winter' |publisher=CBN |accessdate=October 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/the-arab-winter |title= The Arab Winter|work= The New Yorker | accessdate = October 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.spu.edu/about-spu/news/articles/2014/may/arab-spring |title= Arab Spring or Arab Winter?| publisher= The New Yorker | accessdate= October 8, 2014}}</ref> is a term for the resurgence of [[authoritarianism]] and [[Islamic extremism]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Yun Ru Phua |url=http://bpr.berkeley.edu/2015/03/30/after-every-winter-comes-spring-tunisias-democratic-flowering/ |title=After Every Winter Comes Spring: Tunisia’s Democratic Flowering – Berkeley Political Review |publisher=Bpr.berkeley.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-02-11}}</ref> evolving in the aftermath of the [[Arab Spring]] protests in [[Arab League|Arab]] countries.<ref>Ahmed H Adam and Ashley D Robinson. ''Will the Arab Winter spring again in Sudan?''. Al-Jazeera. 11 June 2016. [http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2016/05/arab-winter-spring-sudan-160531082228922.html] "The Arab Spring that swept across the Middle East and succeeded in overthrowing three dictatorships in Tunisia, Egypt and Libya in 2011 was a pivotal point in the history of nations. Despite the subsequent descent into the "Arab Winter", the peaceful protests of young people were heroic..."</ref> The term "Arab Winter" refers to the events across [[Arab League]] countries in the Mid-East and North Africa, including the [[Syrian Civil War]],<ref name="Fear and Faith in Paradise">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com./books?id=__lUxmzAZ08C&pg=PA296 | title =Fear and Faith in Paradise| accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Arab Winter">{{cite web| url = http://americamagazine.org/issue/culture/arab-winter |title=Arab Winter|work=America Staging|accessdate= October 23, 2014}}</ref> the [[Iraqi insurgency (2011–14)|Iraqi insurgency]] and the [[Iraqi Civil War (2014–2017)|following civil war]],<ref name="The Jerusalem Post">{{cite web|url= http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Analysis-Arab-Winter-is-coming-to-Baghdad-359348 |title= Analysis: Arab Winter is coming to Baghdad | work = The Jerusalem Post | accessdate = October 23, 2014}}</ref> the [[Egyptian Crisis (2011–14)|Egyptian Crisis]],<ref name= euronews>{{cite web | url = http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/08/egypt-and-tunisia-s-new-arab-winter/ | title = Egypt and Tunisia’s new ‘Arab winter’ | work = Euro news | accessdate = October 23, 2014}}</ref> the [[Libyan Crisis (2011–present)|Libyan Crisis]] and the [[Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)|Crisis in Yemen]].<ref name="Yemen’s Arab winter">{{cite web| url = http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/yemen-s-arab-winter-1470341500 |title=Yemen’s Arab winter|work= Middle East Eye | accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> Events referred to as the Arab Winter include those in [[Egypt]] that led to the removal of [[Mohamed Morsi]] and the seizure of power by General [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] in an anti-[[Muslim Brotherhood]] campaign.<ref name="euronews.com">{{Citation | title = Egypt & Tunisia’s new Arab winter | newspaper = Euro news | date = February 8, 2013 | url = http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/08/egypt-and-tunisia-s-new-arab-winter/}}</ref>
According to scholars of the [[University of Warsaw]], the Arab Spring fully devolved into the Arab Winter four years after its onset.<ref name="auto">Radoslaw Fiedler, Przemyslaw Osiewicz. ''Transformation processes in Egypt after 2011''. 2015. p182.</ref> The Arab Winter is characterized by the emergence of multiple regional [[civil war]]s, mounting regional instability,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://theconversation.com/from-egypt-to-syria-this-could-be-the-start-of-the-arab-winter-17335 |title= From Egypt to Syria, this could be the start of the Arab Winter|date=April 17, 2014|work= The Conversation | accessdate = October 23, 2014}}</ref> economic and demographic decline of Arab countries,<ref name=rivlin/> and ethno-religious sectarian strife.<ref>{{Citation | last = Malmvig | first = Lassen | title = Arab uprisings: regional implication | publisher = IEMED | year = 2013 | format = PDF | url = http://www.iemed.org/observatori/arees-danalisi/arxius-adjunts/anuari/iemed-2013/Malmvig%20Lassen%20Arab%20Uprisings%20Regional%20Implications%20EN.pdf}}</ref> According to a study by the [[American University of Beirut]], as of the summer of 2014 the Arab Winter had resulted in nearly a quarter of a million deaths and millions of refugees.<ref name="auto1">{{Citation | title = Displacement in the Middle East and North Africa – between the Arab Winter and the Arab Spring | journal = International Affairs | date = August 28, 2013 | format = PDF | publisher = AUB | place = LB | url = http://www.aub.edu.lb/ifi/international_affairs/Documents/working_paper_series/20130828_IA_WP_AUB_Paper_on_Displacement_in_Arab_Spring.pdf}}</ref> Perhaps the most significant event in the Arab Winter was the rise of the extreme [[ISIL]] group, which controlled large swathes of land from 2014.<ref>https://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Analysis-Arab-Winter-is-coming-to-Baghdad-359348</ref>
==Definition== ===Geography=== The term "Arab Winter" refers to the events across [[Arab League]] countries in the Mid-East and North Africa, including the [[Syrian Civil War]],<ref name="Fear and Faith in Paradise">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com./books?id=__lUxmzAZ08C&pg=PA296 | title =Fear and Faith in Paradise| accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Arab Winter">{{cite web| url = http://americamagazine.org/issue/culture/arab-winter |title=Arab Winter|work=America Staging|accessdate= October 23, 2014}}</ref> the [[Iraqi insurgency (2011–14)|Iraqi insurgency]] and the [[Iraqi Civil War (2014–present)|following civil war]],<ref name="The Jerusalem Post">{{cite web|url= http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Analysis-Arab-Winter-is-coming-to-Baghdad-359348 |title= Analysis: Arab Winter is coming to Baghdad | work = The Jerusalem Post | accessdate = October 23, 2014}}</ref> the [[Egyptian Crisis (2011–14)|Egyptian Crisis]],<ref name= euronews>{{cite web | url = http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/08/egypt-and-tunisia-s-new-arab-winter/ | title = Egypt and Tunisia’s new ‘Arab winter’ | work = Euro news | accessdate = October 23, 2014}}</ref> the [[Libyan Crisis (2011–present)|Libyan Crisis]] and the [[Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)|Crisis in Yemen]].<ref name="Yemen’s Arab winter">{{cite web| url = http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/yemen-s-arab-winter-1470341500 |title=Yemen’s Arab winter|work= Middle East Eye | accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> Events referred to as the Arab Winter include those in [[Egypt]] that led to the removal of [[Mohamed Morsi]] and the seizure of power by General [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] in an anti-[[Muslim Brotherhood]] military coup.<ref name="euronews.com">{{Citation | title = Egypt & Tunisia’s new Arab winter | newspaper = Euro news | date = February 8, 2013 | url = http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/08/egypt-and-tunisia-s-new-arab-winter/}}</ref> Political developments, particularly the restoration of authoritarianism and suppression of [[civil liberties]] in Egypt since [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|July 3, 2013]], have been described as constituting a "military winter" that functioned in opposition to the goals of the Arab Spring.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.thenation.com/article/175121/coup-egypt-arab-winter |title = The Coup in Egypt: An Arab Winter?|work=The Nation|date=July 5, 2013|accessdate=November 1, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| publisher = The Huffington Post | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/21/egypt-arab-spring_n_4568523.html | title = In Egypt, Arab Spring Gives Way To Military Winter| work= The World Post| date= January 21, 2014 | accessdate = November 1, 2014}}</ref> Various militias and tribes have started fighting in Libya after a breakdown in negotiations.<ref name = Yom /> The [[Syrian Civil War spillover in Lebanon|arenas of Lebanon]] and [[Bahraini uprising of 2011|Bahrain]] were also identified as areas of the Arab Winter.<ref name=rivlin/> [[Libya]] was named as a scene of the Arab Winter, together with [[Syria]], by Professor Sean Yom.<ref name = Yom>{{cite web| title = Lecture Explores Past and Future Arab Spring | date = October 10, 2014 | url= http://daily.swarthmore.edu/2014/10/10/lecture-explores-past-and-future-arab-spring/ | work = The Daily Gazette | accessdate = October 19, 2014}}</ref> The [[Northern Mali conflict]] was often described as part of the "[[Islamism|Islamist]] Winter".<ref>"In Mali AQ achieved to infiltrate and take over [[Tuareg rebellion (2012)|Tuareg insurgency]]. If AQ succeeds to keep the Arab Spring countries destabilized, this will lead to a viral reproduction of [[Azawad]] scenario. AQ is the "Islamic Winter"." [http://securityobserver.org/the-role-of-al-qaeda-in-mali-a-lesson-for-arab-spring-future/]</ref> Political changes which occurred in [[Tunisia]], involving a change in government, as well as an [[ISIL insurgency in Tunisia|ISIL insurgency]], were also indicated by some as a possible "heading towards Arab Winter".<ref name = "euronews.com" />{{clarify|date=September 2015}}
Chinese professor [[Zhang Weiwei (professor)|Zhang Weiwei]] first predicted "Arab Winter" in his June 2011 debate with [[Francis Fukuyama]], who believed the movement might be spread to China<ref>{{cite web|author=张维为|title=观天下讲坛{{!}} 张维为：话语自信——回望六年前与福山的那场辩论 |url=https://www.guancha.cn/ZhangWeiWei/2017_06_13_412940_s.shtml |website=www.guancha.cn |language=zh-cmn-Hans}}</ref>. "My understanding of the Middle East leads me to conclude that the west should not be too happy. It will bring enormous problems to American interest. It is called "Arab Spring" for now, and I guess it will soon turn to be the winter for the Middle East."<ref>{{cite web|title=谁的终结？——福山与张维为对话“中国模式”-张维为、弗朗西斯·福山 |url=https://www.guancha.cn/ZhangWeiWei/2011_11_01_61959.shtml |website=guancha |accessdate=2 August 2018 |language=zh-cmn-Hans|quote=而且我自己对中东的了解使我得出这样的结论，西方千万不要太高兴，这会给美国的利益会带来很多的问题。现在叫中东的春天，我看不久就要变成中东的冬天。}}</ref>
===Chronology=== According to scholars of the [[University of Warsaw]], the Arab Spring fully devolved into the Arab Winter four years after its onset.<ref name="auto"/> This view was also supported by Prof. James Y. Simms Jr. in his 2017 opinion article for the ''Richmond Times''.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=http://www.richmond.com/opinion/their-opinion/guest-columnists/arab-spring-to-arab-winter-a-predictable-debacle-in-the/article_74b2f2b1-f269-502d-b25f-7b4d0552d28f.html |title=Arab Spring to Arab Winter: a predictable debacle in the Middle East|author=James Y. Simms, Jr.|website=richmond.com|accessdate=July 7, 2017}}</ref> In early 2016, ''The Economist'' marked the situation across Arab world countries as "worse than ever", marking it as the ongoing Arab Winter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21685503-five-years-after-wave-uprisings-arab-world-worse-ever |title=The Arab winter|publisher=''The Economist''|accessdate=July 7, 2017}}</ref>
==Impact== ===Economic impact=== According to the [[Moshe Dayan Center for Middle Eastern and African Studies]], as of January 2014, the cost of Arab Winter upheaval across the Arab World was some 800 billion [[United States dollar|USD]].<ref name= rivlin>{{Citation | title = Iqtisadi | date = Jan 2014 | url = http://www.dayan.org/sites/default/files/Iqtisadi%202014/Iqtisadi_Jan_14_ENG.pdf | last = Rivlin | first = P | publisher = Dayan Research Center}}</ref> Some 16 million people in Syria, Egypt, [[Iraq]], [[Jordan]] and [[Lebanon]] were expected to require humanitarian assistance in 2014.<ref name=rivlin />
According to ''[[The Economist]]'', [[Malta]] has "benefited" from the Arab Winter, as tourists who might otherwise be in Egypt or Tunisia opt for a safer alternative.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21678248-migrants-once-flocked-malta-host-eu-african-migration-summit-not-anymore-high-wall |title=High wall, narrow sea|publisher=''The Economist''|accessdate=July 7, 2017}}</ref>
===Casualties=== According to a study by the [[American University of Beirut]], as of the summer of 2014 the Arab Winter had resulted in nearly a quarter of a million deaths and millions of refugees.<ref name="auto1"/>
Political columnist and commentator [[George Will]] reported that as of early 2017, over 30,000 lives had been lost in Libya, 220,000-320,000 had been killed in Syria and 4 million refugees had been produced by the Syrian Civil War alone.<ref name="auto2"/>
===Migrant crisis=== {{main|European migrant crisis}} [[File:Syrian_refugee_camp_on_theTurkish_border.jpg|300px|thumb|right| Syrian refugee camp on the Turkish border for displaced people of the Syrian civil war (2012)]] The political turmoil and violence in the Middle East and [[North Africa]] resulted in [[European migrant crisis|massive population displacement in the region]].<ref>''“Displacement in the Middle East and North Africa: Between an Arab Winter and the Arab Spring”''. "In the midst of ongoing uprisings, violence, and political turmoil, widespread population displacement took place as a result of the conflict in Libya, the violence in Syria and upheaval in Yemen. In each of these contexts, the new waves of displacement took place in or to areas already struggling with previous waves, leading to multi-layered and complex crises."[https://www.aub.edu.lb/ifi/international_affairs/Documents/working_paper_series/20130828_IA_WP_AUB_Paper_on_Displacement_in_Arab_Spring.pdf]</ref> As a result, “boat-people”, which was once commonly referred to [[Vietnamese boat people]], became frequently used, including internally displaced persons and asylum-seekers and refugees who had previously been residing in Libya, have headed towards the [[European Union]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Khallaf|first=Shaden|date=August 2013|title=Displacement in the Middle East and North Africa: Between an Arab Winter and the Arab Spring|url=https://www.aub.edu.lb/ifi/international_affairs/Documents/working_paper_series/20130828_IA_WP_AUB_Paper_on_Displacement_in_Arab_Spring.pdf|journal=|series=Working Paper Series|publisher=Issam Fares Institute for Public Policy and International Affairs, American University of Beirut|volume=|issue=17|pages=|via=}}</ref> The attempts by some Libyans and Tunisians to seek safety from the violence by crossing the Mediterranean sea have triggered fears among European politicians and populations of arrivals that might "flood" their shores. This has spurred a flurry of legislative activity and patrolling of the waters to manage arrivals.<ref name=":0" /> {{-}}

{{refimprove|date=April 2013}} The '''British Book Awards''' or '''Nibbies''' are [[literary award]]s for the best UK writers and their works, administered by ''[[The Bookseller]]''. The awards have had several previous names, owners and sponsors since being launched in 1990, including the '''National Book Awards''' from 2010-2014.
==Book award history==
The '''British Book Awards''' or '''Nibbies''' ran from 1990–2009 and founded by the editor of ''[[Publishing News]]''.<ref name="hist">{{cite web|title=The British Book Awards - a History|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/british-book-awards/history|publisher=The Bookseller|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> The award was then acquired by [[Agile Marketing]] which renamed it the '''National Book Awards''' with headline sponsors '''Galaxy National Book Awards''' (2010–11) (sponsored by [[Galaxy (chocolate)|Galaxy]]) and '''Specsavers National Book Awards''' (2012-2014) (sponsored by [[Specsavers]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalbookawards.co.uk:80/about-the-awards/ |title=About the awards |work=nationalbookawards.co.uk |author= |date= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119001303/http://www.nationalbookawards.co.uk/about-the-awards/# |archivedate=2012-11-19 |deadurl=yes |quote=Before 2010 the awards were known as the British Book Awards. Specsavers became the sponsor of the 2012 awards, the new deal follows the previous 5-year partnership with Galaxy. |access-date=2012-11-05 |df= }}</ref> There were no National Book Awards after 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalbookawards.co.uk |title=National Book Awards homepage |work=National Book Awards |author= |date= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104050017/http://www.nationalbookawards.co.uk/ |archivedate=4 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |quote=There will be no event during 2015 and no date yet set for title submissions |df= }}</ref> In 2017 the award was acquired by ''The Bookseller'' and renamed to the original '''British Book Awards''' or '''Nibbies'''..<ref name="hist"/>
In 2005, ''The Bookseller'' launched a separate scheme, The Bookseller Retail Awards (winners not listed in this article). In 2010, running parallel to the National Book Awards, ''The Bookseller'' combined The Nibbies with its retail awards to produce '''The Bookseller Industry Awards''' (winners not listed in this article). In 2017 '''The British Book Industry Awards''' were renamed as The British Book Awards after it acquired the National Book Awards from Agile Marketing.<ref name="hist"/>
It is known as the ''Nibbies'' because of the golden [[nib (pen)|nib]]-shaped trophy given to winners.<ref name="about2017">{{cite web|title=About the British Book Awards|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/british-book-awards/about|publisher=The Bookseller|accessdate=11 August 2017|date=2017}}</ref>

The '''C.V. Starr Center for the Study of the American Experience''' is an institute at [[Washington College]], in [[Chestertown, Maryland]], that promotes the research and study of American history and culture. Founded in 2000, the [[C.V. Starr]] Center at Washington College is one of many educational initiatives funded by the [[Starr Foundation]], a private foundation with assets of over $1.25 billion.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Starr Foundation|accessdate=October 2, 2011|url=http://www.starrfoundation.org/index.html}}</ref> The inaugural director of the C.V. Starr Center, [[Edward L. Widmer]], served under [[Bill Clinton]] as special assistant to the president for national security affairs; among other accomplishments, he wrote foreign policy speeches and advised the president on topics related to history and scholarship as senior advisor to the president for special projects.<ref>{{cite news|title=Edward L. Widmer Named New Director of John Carter Brown Library|publisher=[[Brown University]]|date=January 10, 2006|url=http://www.brown.edu/Administration/News_Bureau/2005-06/05-062.html}}</ref> Since 2006, Adam Goodheart, a historian, journalist and author of ''1861: The Civil War Awakening'', has served as director of the Center.<ref>{{cite web|title=About The Center|publisher=Washington College|url=http://www.washcoll.edu/centers/starr/about-the-center.php |accessdate=May 15, 2013}}</ref> In addition to its academic components, the C.V. Starr Center works closely with external groups to sponsor events of public interest, such as the Poplar Grove Project, a recovery and recordation project in collaboration with the [[Maryland State Archives]], and hosts readings and lectures often focused on topics of local interest, such as [[Chesapeake Bay]] history.<ref>{{cite web|title=James Wood Poplar Grove Collection|publisher=Maryland State Archives |accessdate=May 15, 2013|url=http://speccol.mdarchives.state.md.us/msa/speccol/catalog/cfm/dsp_number.cfm?speccol=5807}}</ref><ref>Buckley, Michael. [http://christopherwhitebooks.com/news/skipjack-event-at-washington-college-april-25-2010 "Skipjack Event at Washington College: April 25, 2010"]. [[Christopher White Books]]. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref>
==Location and History== [[File:WashingtonCollege.CustomHouse.jpg|thumb|250px|18th century Custom House]] The C.V. Starr Center for the Study of the American Experience is headquartered in Chestertown’s Custom House, a building constructed in the 1740s by Samuel Massey as a residence for the Ringgold family and known for its detailed Flemish bond brickwork with glazed headers.,<ref>[http://www.chestertown.com/distinctive_destination.php "National Trust Names Chestertown, Md., One of America’s Dozen Distinctive Destinations"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111029072318/http://www.chestertown.com/distinctive_destination.php# |date=2011-10-29 }}. Chestertown, Maryland. March 7, 2007.</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>Janson-La Paime, Robert J. H. [http://www.chestertown.com/places/tour.htm "Chestertown: An Architectural Guide"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315015825/http://www.chestertown.com/places/tour.htm# |date=2012-03-15 }}. Chestertown, Maryland. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref> The location, beside the public dock at the intersection of High and Water Streets, has always been central to much of Chestertown’s daily activity in commerce, industry, and tourism. Over its 200+ year history, the Custom House has changed hands several times. Senator [[James Alfred Pearce]], who later chaired the Joint Library Committee of Congress and served on the Smithsonian Institution’s Board of Regents, lived in the Custom House in the late 19th century.<ref>Ostrowski, Carl (2000). [https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/25548814?uid=3738032&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21102286453237 "James Alfred Pearce and the Question of a National Library in Antebellum America"] {{subscription required}}. ''Libraries and Culture'' '''35''' (2): 255.</ref> One of the building’s most influential owners, Wilbur Ross Hubbard, carried out a major renovation and restoration project in the 1970s before bequeathing the house to Washington College.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20111004122033/http://www.kentcountyhistory.org/house_tour/ "Programs and Events"]. Historical Society of Kent County. Archived from [http://www.kentcountyhistory.org/house_tour/ the original] on October 4, 2011.</ref> The front portico is another recent addition, designed by consultant Michael Bourne to integrate local motifs. Buildings of this style, size, and period are now rare in the territory that once comprised the original 13 colonies.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> In 1969, the [[National Park Service]] recognized the Custom House on the National Survey of Historic Sites and Buildings.<ref>{{NHLS url|id=70000263|title="Chestertown Historic District, Chestertown, Maryland"}}. The National Survey of Historic Sites and Buildings. National Park Service. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref> In addition to the C.V. Starr Center, the Custom House serves as home to the Center for Environment & Society and the Washington College Archaeology Lab.
==Events, Programs, and Projects== The Starr Center hosts numerous public events, including talks by visiting authors, museum programs, concerts, panel discussions and public conversations on American culture. Recent speakers have included Senators [[Birch Bayh]] and [[Richard Lugar]], filmmaker [[John Waters]], actress [[Anna Deavere Smith]], journalist [[Michael R. Meyer|Michael Meyer]], civil rights attorney [[Sherrilyn Ifill]], novelist [[James McBride (writer)|James McBride]] and historians [[James M. McPherson|James McPherson]], [[Annette Gordon-Reed]] and [[David Blight]].
The '''“History on the Waterfront”''' multimedia program, launched in 2009, is a free thirty-minute audio-guided tour recreating the sights and sounds of an 18th-century working waterfront.<ref>[http://search.visitmaryland.org/visitsearch/vmattraction?attractionNumber=0&attractionID=6904 "History on the Waterfront Audio Tour"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425092831/http://search.visitmaryland.org/visitsearch/vmattraction?attractionNumber=0&attractionID=6904# |date=2012-04-25 }}. Maryland Office of Tourism. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref> The tour provides a walk back in time into an era when local streets bustled with revolutionaries and convicts, slave traders, British soldiers and heroes of the [[Underground Railroad]]. “History on the Waterfront” was researched, written and performed by Washington College students, faculty and staff, along with members of the Chestertown community, and includes narrative, music, reenactments and firsthand accounts of life in the colonial port. The program was orchestrated by the Starr Center's associate director, Jill Ogline Titus, and narrated by the Center’s director, Adam Goodheart. The Center’s program manager, Michael Buckley, who also produces the weekly radio series "Voices of the Chesapeake Bay" on [[103.1 WRNR]], oversaw the technical aspects of the production.<ref>[http://www.wrnr.com/page.php?jock_id=6983&page_id=39975 "Voices of the Bay"]. WRNR-FM. Empire Broadcast System. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref> The “History on the Waterfront” tour is free of charge and available year-round.
'''The Riverfront Concert Series''', which debuted in 2010, offers free musical performances throughout the summer on the riverfront lawn of the Custom House. Performers in the 2010 series included singer-songwriter [[Bob Zentz]] and acoustic guitar duo Mac Walter & John Cronin.<ref>Goddard, Andy (July 17, 2010). [http://www.chestertownspy.com/wc-riverside-concerts-start-july-27-with-chesapeake-bays-bob-zentz/ "WC Riverside Concerts Start July 27 with Chesapeake Bay's Bob Zentz"]. Chestertown Spy.</ref> The series builds on the Starr Center’s longstanding interest in the musical traditions of Chesapeake Bay and its rich heritage of storytelling.
The Poplar Grove Plantation, near [[Centreville, Maryland]], is the location of the '''Poplar Grove Project''', an ongoing exploration of the Emory family’s papers, some dating back as far as the 17th century. Starr Center director Adam Goodheart began initial excavations at Poplar Grove in 2003 with the Archaeology Field School at Washington College, and in 2008, one of his students discovered the collection of papers. In conjunction with the Maryland State Archives, the Poplar Grove project seeks to preserve, document and study this large collection. Current Poplar Grove owner James Wood, a descendant of the Emory family, has been a source of information for Goodheart’s students as they participate in the project.<ref>Blair, Elizabeth (July 3, 2008). [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=92190792 "In A Crumbling House, A Trove Of Everyday History"]. ''[[All Things Considered]]''. [[National Public Radio]].</ref> His mother, Mary Wood, published a book about the Emory women called ''My Darling Alice: Based on Letters and Legends of an Eastern Shore of Maryland Farm – 1837 – 1935''. To date, over 28,406 documents have been recovered and scanned into digital files that will be published online.<ref>[[Edward C. Papenfuse|Papenfuse, Edward C.]] [http://mdhistory.net/msaref11/msa_sc_5807_01/html/index.html "Poplar Grove A. M. Hemsley Emory Correspondence"]. MDhistory.net. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref>
'''The [[George Washington Book Prize]]''' recognizes the year's best books on the nation's founding era, especially those with the potential to advance broad public understanding of American history. Sponsored by Washington College, the [[Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History]], and [[George Washington]]’s [[Mount Vernon]], and administered by the Starr Center, the $50,000 award is one of the largest literary prizes in America. In 2005, the inaugural book prize was awarded to [[Ron Chernow]] for his biography ''Alexander Hamilton''.<ref>Wyatt, Edward (May 9, 2005). [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E7DB1230F93AA35756C0A9639C8B63&ref=ronchernow&emc=eta1 "Arts, Briefly; Prize for 'Hamilton' Author"]. ''The New York Times''.</ref> Other winners have included [[Richard Beeman]] (2010) for ''Plain, Honest Men: The Making of the American Constitution'',<ref>Atkinson, Steven G. (May 20, 2010). [http://delmarvatowncrier.com/archives/richard-beeman-wins-george-washington-book-prize/ "Richard Beeman Wins George Washington Book Prize"]. Delmarva Town Crier.</ref> [[Annette Gordon-Reed]] (2009) for ''[[The Hemingses of Monticello]]'',<ref>[http://news.rutgers.edu/medrel/news-releases/2009/05/another-prestigious-20090529 "Another Prestigious Literary Honor for Rutgers University, Newark, Professor Annette Gordon-Reed: the 2009 George Washington Book Prize for 'The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family'"]. Rutgers University. May 29, 2009.</ref> [[Marcus Rediker]] (2008) for ''The Slave Ship: A Human History'',<ref>White, Patricia Lomando (June 9, 2010). [https://web.archive.org/web/20100613014539/http://www.chronicle.pitt.edu/?p=1466 "Award-Winning Pitt Historian Marcus Rediker Receives George Washington Book Prize"]. ''Pitt Chronicle''. University of Pittsburgh. Archived from [http://www.chronicle.pitt.edu/?p=1466 the original] on June 13, 2010.</ref> and [[Stacy Schiff]] (2006) for ''A Great Improvisation: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America''.<ref>Van der Gaag, Chelsea (May 24, 2006). [https://web.archive.org/web/20120404142441/http://www.gilderlehrman.org/pressroom/news.php?headline_id=1032 "$50,000 George Washington Book Prize Awarded To Pulitzer-Winner Stacy Schiff; Dinner at Historic Mount Vernon honors best book on the founding era"]. The Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History. Archived from [http://www.gilderlehrman.org/pressroom/news.php?headline_id=1032 the original] on April 4, 2010.</ref> In 2011, [[Pauline Maier]] was awarded the prize for her book ''Ratification: The People Debate the Constitution. 1787–1788''.<ref>[http://web.mit.edu/pmaier/www/maier.htm "Pauline R. Maier"]. Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref>
'''The Patrick Henry Writing Fellowship''' offers a nine-month residency to authors doing innovative work on America’s founding era and its legacy. Launched by the Starr Center in 2008, the fellowship is permanently endowed as part of a $2.5 million challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities’ “We the People” initiative.<ref>[http://www.wethepeople.gov/projects/2007grants.html "2007 We the People Grants"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717225303/http://www.wethepeople.gov/projects/2007grants.html# |date=2010-07-17 }}. We the People. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref> The Henry Fellowship includes a $45,000 stipend and residency in the restored circa-1735 Patrick Fellows’ Residence. Co-sponsored by the Rose O’Neill Literary House, Washington College’s center for literature and the literary arts, the fellowship aims to encourage reflection on the links between [[American history]] and contemporary culture, and to foster the literary art of historical writing. The annual application deadline is February 15. Inaugural Patrick Henry Writing Fellow, historian and author [[Henry Wiencek]], spent his residency working on an upcoming book about [[Thomas Jefferson]] and his slaves and teaching a class at Washington College.<ref>[http://hnn.us/roundup/entries/52587.html "Henry Wiencek: Named Washington College's First Patrick Henry Fellow"]. George Mason University's [[History News Network]]. July 22, 2008.</ref> The 2009–10 fellowship recipient, Marla Miller, recently published a biography of flag-maker [[Betsy Ross]], ''Betsy Ross and the Making of America'', completed during her residence.<ref>Smith, Jay. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120406073231/http://history.unc.edu/interview-marla-miller "Interview: Marla Miller"]. University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Department of History. Archived from [http://history.unc.edu/interview-marla-miller the original] on April 6, 2012.</ref>
The Patrick Henry Fellows’ Residence, known traditionally as the Buck-Chambers House, has strong connections to three centuries of American history. Its past owners include a British merchant active in the convict trade to Chesapeake Bay, a [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] officer who served with [[George Washington]] in the famous [[New York campaign of 1776]], and a U.S. senator who led a Kent County militia company into battle during the [[War of 1812]]. Purchased by Washington College in 2007, the house underwent a year-long restoration before welcoming the first Patrick Henry Visiting Fellow in September 2008.<ref>[http://www.washcoll.edu/centers/starr/the-patrick-henry-fellows-residence-a-short-history.php "The Patrick Henry Fellows' Residence: A Short History"]. Washington College. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref>
'''The Hodson Trust – John Carter Brown Fellowship''' supports work by academics, independent scholars and writers working on significant projects relating to the literature, history, culture or art of the Americas before 1830. The fellowship is also open to filmmakers, novelists, creative and performing artists, and others working on projects that draw on this period of history. The award supports two months of research at the [[John Carter Brown Library]] in [[Providence, RI]], and two months of writing at the Starr Center, and comes with a stipend of $20,000, plus housing and university privileges at both institutions. The annual application deadline is March 15.<ref>[http://www.brown.edu/academics/libraries/john-carter-brown/fellowships/jcb-fellowship-program "The JCB Fellowship Program"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528132805/http://www.brown.edu/academics/libraries/john-carter-brown/fellowships/jcb-fellowship-program# |date=2013-05-28 }}. The John Carter Brown Library at Brown University. Retrieved May 15, 2013.</ref>

{{More citations needed|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name= Carrie Dormon | image = Caroline Dormon holding a flower.jpg | nationality= [[United States|American]] | birth_name = Caroline Coroneos Dormon | birth_date= {{Birth date|1888|7|19}} | death_date= {{death date and age|1971|11|21|1888|7|19}} | death_place= [[Shreveport, Louisiana]], U.S. | resting_place= Briarwood Baptist Church Cemetery near [[Saline, Louisiana|Saline]], Louisiana, U.S. | birth_place= [[Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana]], U.S. | occupation= [[Botanist]], artist, author, conservationist | alma_mater= [[Judson College (Alabama)|Judson College, Marion, Alabama]] }}
'''Caroline Coroneos Dormon''', also known as '''Carrie Dormon''' (July 19, 1888 – November 21, 1971), was an American [[botanist]], [[horticulturist]], [[ornithologist]], [[historian]], [[archeologist]], [[preservationist]], [[natural history|naturalist]], [[conservation movement|conservationist]], and [[author]] from [[Louisiana]].
She was born in modest circumstances at Briarwood,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.briarwoodnp.org|title=Home|website=Briarwood Nature Preserve|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref> the family home in northern [[Natchitoches Parish]], to James L. Dormon and the former Caroline Trotti. She was reared a [[Southern Baptist]] in [[Arcadia, Louisiana|Arcadia]], the [[County seat|parish seat of government]] of [[Bienville Parish]], in northern Louisiana. She never married.
==Background== As a child, Dormon developed a great interest in plants and wildlife. She was educated at the [[Baptist]]-affiliated [[Judson College (Alabama)|Judson College, Marion, Alabama]], from which she received a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[literature]] and [[art]]. She taught for several years in Louisiana schools, and then re-established her home at Briarwood in 1918. She began to collect and preserve native trees and shrubs.<ref name="lahistory.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.lahistory.org/site21.php|title=Dictionary of Louisiana Biography - C - Louisiana Historical Association|website=Lahistory.org|accessdate=5 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160925003659/http://www.lahistory.org/site21.php|archive-date=2016-09-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Diversified career== {{more citations needed|section|date=December 2017}} In 1921, she became a [[public relations]] representative for the Louisiana Forestry Department. She attended a Southern Forestry Congress in 1922 and persuaded the [[United States Forest Service]] to establish a national forest in Louisiana. [[U.S. Representative]] [[James B. Aswell]] of [[Natchitoches, Louisiana|Natchitoches]] worked with Dormon to bring to fruition the [[Kisatchie National Forest]], which was designated in 1930 during President [[Herbert Hoover]]'s administration.<ref name="lahistory.org"/>
In 1941, during the administration of [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[Sam H. Jones|Sam Houston Jones]], Dormon joined the Louisiana Highway Department (later the Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development) as beautification consultant. She was later a landscape consultant for the [[Huey P. Long]] Charity Hospital in [[Pineville, Louisiana]] east of the [[Red River of the South|Red River]]. She also served as consultant for Hodges Gardens.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hodgesgardens.com/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2006-12-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061205043241/http://hodgesgardens.com/ |archive-date=2006-12-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Dormon also proposed what became the [[Louisiana State Arboretum]], located some eight miles (13 km) north of [[Ville Platte, Louisiana|Ville Platte]], the seat of [[Evangeline Parish]], as part of nearby Chicot State Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friendslaarb.org/aboutus.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220191059/http://www.friendslaarb.org/aboutus.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 February 2007|title=About The Louisiana State Arboretum|date=20 February 2007|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref> The {{convert|301|acre|km2|adj=on}} site was dedicated in 1964. The Caroline Dormon Lodge opened in 1965, serving as a visitor center, library, and herbarium of native plants which grow within the boundaries of the arboretum.<ref name="LouisianaArboretum">{{cite book|editor-last=Peak|editor-first=Myra F.|publisher=Governor's Office of Federal Affairs and Special Projects|title=Louisiana Arboretum|accessdate=2011-03-25}}</ref>
Her published works include: ''Wild Flowers of Louisiana'' (1934), ''Forest Trees of Louisiana'' (1941), ''Flowers Native to the Deep South'' (1958), ''Natives Preferred'' (1965), ''Southern Indian Boy'' (1967), and ''Bird Talk'' (1969).{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
Dormon was the only woman member of the De Soto Commission established by Congress in 1935 to commemorate the 400th anniversary of [[Hernando de Soto (explorer)|Hernando de Soto]]'s expedition across the American Southeast, which crossed northern Louisiana.
In 1965, she was presented with an honorary Doctor of Science award from [[Louisiana State University]] in [[Baton Rouge]]. The Dormon Collection is located at the [[Eugene P. Watson]] Memorial Library of [[Northwestern State University]] in Natchitoches.
In August 2012, the [[Rapides Parish School Board]] opened Caroline Dormon Junior High School Woodworth. The school is located on a {{convert|33|acre|m2|adj=on}} site, off [[U.S. Highway 165]]. Land for the school was donated by the [[United States Forest Service]] from the [[Kisatchie National Forest]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r8/kisatchie/kisatchie-rd/trails/dormon.htm|title=Kisatchie National Forest - Home|website=Fs.fed.us|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
The K-8th grade school cost $6.5 million and is a “green” school with energy saving tweaks such as solar panels, building and roofing colors, and efficiency of the mechanical and electrical systems. The {{convert|50,000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} school is expected to open with approximately three hundred pupils.
==Death and legacy== Dormon died in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]]. She is interred at the Briarwood Baptist Church Cemetery near her home. Dormon willed her home, Briarwood, to the public. Located near [[Saline, Louisiana|Saline]] in southern Bienville Parish, it is the headquarters of the Caroline Dormon Nature Preserve.<ref>{{HALS|survey=LA-1|id=la0496|title=Briarwood: The Caroline Dormon Nature Preserve, 216 Caroline Dormon Road, Saline, Bienville Parish, Louisiana|photos=56|color=10|data=85|cap=6}}</ref>
Natchitoches attorney and [[philanthropist]] [[Arthur C. Watson]] organized the Foundation for the Preservation of the Caroline Dormon Nature Preserve and served as its treasurer until his death in 1984. The Caroline Dormon Trail extending {{convert|10.5|mi|km}} in the Kisatchie Bayou Recreation Complex within the national forest. The trail starts at the Longleaf Scenic Byway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.explorenatchitoches.com/outdoors.php?task=view&articleID=87|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403060704/http://www.explorenatchitoches.com/outdoors.php?task=view&articleID=87|dead-url=yes|archive-date=3 April 2007|title=Natchitoches.net : Outdoor Recreation|date=3 April 2007|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
In 1972, an art show named in Dormon's honor was formed in Shreveport by Emmett Elmo Rhodes. For twenty-six years, this annual art show and festival ran to promote nature art in "Miss Carrie's" name which eventually received entries from all over the state. The show had two divisions, Children's Division and Adult Division. It was held at different venues located in Shreveport and was first held at the R.S. Barnwell Art and Garden Center, then at Mall St. Vincent, then at the Louisiana State Exhibit Museum.
